questions.text:
A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of upper abdominal discomfort and yellowing of the eyes. Over the past 3 months, his appetite has decreased and he has become increasingly nauseous. He smells of alcohol when he enters the office. The patient started drinking 15 years ago and now consumes a pint of liquor every day. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild scleral icterus and conjunctival pallor. Abdominal examination shows mildly tender hepatomegaly. Results of laboratory studies are most likely to show which of the following in this patient?



Aspartate aminotransferase (U/L)
Alanine aminotransferase (U/L)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This set of labs shows elevated serum aminotransferases (AST, ALT) and GGT levels, both of which are seen in alcohol-associated liver disease. However, an AST/ALT ratio < 1 is inconsistent with liver damage due to alcohol use. Moreover, a normal MCV is an unlikely finding in a patient with chronic heavy drinking and conjunctival pallor. This constellation of findings may be seen in metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASH), which is a diagnosis of exclusion in patients with no history of chronic heavy drinking.

B) INCORRECT:

This set of labs shows both ALT and AST elevated > 25× upper limit of normal, which is consistent with acute liver injury caused by massive damage to hepatocytes (e.g., acetaminophen toxicity, viral hepatitis). While GGT elevation is seen in both acute liver injury and alcohol-associated liver disease, the latter is not associated with such an extreme increase in serum aminotransferases. Moreover, a normal MCV is an unlikely finding in a patient with chronic heavy drinking and conjunctival pallor.

C) INCORRECT:

This set of labs shows an isolated elevation of AST, which can be seen with muscle damage or myocardial infarction. Although an increase of AST is expected in alcohol-associated liver disease, an isolated elevation is not specific for liver disease because AST is found in many types of tissue. Moreover, a normal MCV is an unlikely finding in a patient with chronic alcohol use and conjunctival pallor.

D) CORRECT:

This set of labs is consistent with alcohol-associated hepatitis, which fits with this patient's clinical presentation (i.e., chronic alcohol use, hepatomegaly, scleral icterus). The moderate elevation of serum aminotransferase with an AST/ALT ratio > 1.5 seen here is characteristic of this condition and indicates severe hepatocellular injury. A finding of elevated GGT is a strong indicator of excessive alcohol consumption over a period of several weeks. In addition, an MCV > 100 μm3 indicates macrocytosis, which is a typical consequence of excessive drinking that results from alcohol-induced bone marrow toxicity; megaloblastic anemia as a result of poor nutrition (i.e., folate deficiency or vitamin B12 deficiency) is also common. While an isolated GGT elevation is sometimes the only indicator of heavy alcohol use, carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT) is a more specific marker to detect alcohol use disorder.

The most appropriate next step in management is to provide counseling on alcohol abuse, including information about psychosocial support groups (e.g., Alcoholics Anonymous) and pharmacological treatment options (e.g., naltrexone, disulfiram).

E) INCORRECT:

This set of labs shows elevation of both ALT and AST, which is typical of alcohol-associated hepatitis. However, an AST/ALT ratio < 1 is inconsistent with liver damage due to chronic heavy drinking. Moreover, although this patient's conjunctival pallor indicates concomitant anemia, an MCV < 80 μm3 would not be expected. This constellation of findings may be seen in celiac disease. Hypertransaminasemia is present in nearly 50% of patients with celiac disease at the time of diagnosis and indicates subclinical hepatitis that may progress to severe liver disease and cirrhosis; microcytic anemia due to iron deficiency is the most common hematological manifestation.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has alcohol-associated hepatitis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man with a history of alcohol use disorder and no known chronic liver disease is hospitalized with jaundice and a 2-week history of constant, severe pain in the right upper quadrant. He has a poor appetite and has had several episodes of nonbloody emesis. He typically drinks a half-pint of vodka daily, although he stopped drinking alcohol 7 days before coming to the hospital. He is not taking acetaminophen.
On examination, his temperature is 37.5°C, his heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 110/55 mm Hg. His sclerae are icteric. His heart and lung examinations are unremarkable. He is tender to palpation in the right upper quadrant. The liver span is 18 cm; shifting dullness is present. He is oriented to person, place, and time.

Hepatitis C antibody and hepatitis B surface antigen are not detected.
An abdominal ultrasound reveals an enlarged liver with coarsened echotexture, consistent with fatty infiltration. There is no gallbladder wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid. A diagnostic paracentesis finds no evidence of bacterial peritonitis.
Urinalysis shows no evidence of infection, and blood cultures reveal no growth.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lactulose is used to treat hepatic encephalopathy, but it is not indicated in the management of acute alcohol-associated hepatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Ursodeoxycholic acid is used to prevent gallstone formation and is not indicated in the management of alcohol-associated hepatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is best known for its use in treating acute liver injury secondary to acetaminophen. Emerging data suggest that adding NAC to prednisolone might be beneficial in severe acute alcohol-associated hepatitis, with improved short-term mortality and reduced rates of infection and hepatorenal syndrome. Further studies are required before combination NAC-glucocorticoid therapy can be considered standard of care. There is no evidence supporting the use of NAC monotherapy in this setting.

D) CORRECT:

Abdominal pain and jaundice in a patient with an aspartate aminotransferase level that is > 1.5 times the alanine aminotransferase level in the setting of heavy alcohol use is consistent with acute alcohol-associated hepatitis. A liver biopsy would be needed to make a definite diagnosis of alcohol-associated hepatitis, but in the absence of confounding factors (such as uncertain alcohol use assessment, atypical laboratory tests, or possible other etiologies such as ischemic hepatitis, metabolic liver disease, or drug-induced liver disease), a clinical diagnosis is usually sufficient.

In patients with alcohol-associated hepatitis, the severity of disease should be assessed using the MELD score, which takes creatinine, bilirubin, INR, and plasma sodium levels into account. A MELD score of >20 is considered severe and is associated with a 90-day mortality rate of 20%. This patient has a MELD score of 28 and an extremely high bilirubin level of 28 mg/dL; this is indicative of severe hepatitis.

All patients with alcohol-associated hepatitis should cease alcohol consumption and be monitored for alcohol withdrawal. In patients with severe alcohol-associated hepatitis, treatment with glucocorticoids (typically prednisolone 40 mg daily) is recommended unless there is a contraindication (e.g., uncontrolled infection). Although individual trials have yielded inconsistent results about the benefits of glucocorticoid treatment, a meta-analysis of individual patient data from published studies showed a reduction in 28-day mortality.

After 7 days of glucocorticoid treatment, response to therapy should be assessed, typically with the Lille model. This model takes into account certain baseline factors (age, albumin and creatinine levels, and prothrombin time), as well as the bilirubin level on day 7, to classify patients receiving glucocorticoids as either responders (score, <0.45 points) or nonresponders. Other treatment strategies should be considered for nonresponders.

Although pentoxifylline showed promise as an effective treatment for severe alcohol-associated hepatitis in earlier studies, more recent and higher-quality data failed to confirm any benefit; pentoxifylline treatment is therefore not recommended.

Key learning point: The most appropriate therapy for a patient with severe acute alcohol-associated hepatitis who has no evidence of an acute infection is a glucocorticoid.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin E may be helpful in the treatment of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease but has no role in the management of alcohol-associated hepatitis.

A 38-year-old woman with no prior medical care reports one week of right upper quadrant pain and anorexia. She reports consuming a 12-pack of beer daily for the past 5 years and, since recently losing her job, has also been drinking a bottle of wine daily. She notes, though, that she has consumed no alcohol during the past week.
On physical examination, she is jaundiced with a distended abdomen, bulging flanks, and tender hepatomegaly.

None of the following markers are detected on laboratory testing: hepatitis A immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibody, hepatitis B surface antigen, hepatitis B surface antibody, hepatitis B core IgM antibody, hepatitis C antibody.
A right upper quadrant Doppler ultrasound shows an enlarged liver with heterogeneous hepatic echotexture but no focal lesions. The common bile duct is not distended. A moderate amount of ascites is evident. The portal and hepatic veins are patent. Findings on diagnostic paracentesis rule out spontaneous bacterial peritonitis and are consistent with ascites due to portal hypertension.
Which one of the following tests, if any, should be performed at this stage to diagnose this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Liver elastography is a noninvasive test of liver fibrosis and would be helpful in assessing the degree of liver scarring in this patient given her risk for underlying chronic liver disease. However, it would not be an appropriate next test, as it is not diagnostic of alcohol-associated hepatitis and may also overestimate the degree of fibrosis in the setting of acute inflammation.

B) CORRECT:

Alcohol-associated hepatitis is a clinical diagnosis that should be considered in patients with a history of heavy alcohol use who present with nonspecific symptoms, such as jaundice, fever, anorexia, and tender hepatomegaly. The ratio of aspartate aminotransferase (AST) to alanine aminotransferase (ALT) in affected patients is typically > 1.5, and patients may also have other laboratory evidence of liver damage, such as an elevated total bilirubin level, an elevated prothrombin time, or both — in addition to a leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance. Notably, the degree of AST and ALT elevation is typically moderate and rarely > 400 U/liter. Before making the diagnosis of alcohol-associated hepatitis, the clinician should rule out common alternate causes of acute hepatitis, such as viral hepatitis and biliary obstruction, by sending serologic tests for hepatitis A, B, and C and obtaining a right upper quadrant ultrasound. In this patient with a classic history for alcohol-associated hepatitis, alternate diagnoses have already been ruled out; therefore, no additional testing is required to make the diagnosis. Instead, the patient should be treated with supportive therapy, and prednisolone should be considered given the elevated discriminant function.

Key learning point: The diagnosis of alcohol-associated hepatitis is made by ruling out other causes of acute hepatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with alcohol-associated hepatitis often have such severe symptoms that they cannot tolerate alcohol consumption in the days leading up to presentation. The serum ethanol level is thus often undetectable and is not used in diagnosing alcohol-associated hepatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Measuring the serum ferritin level and calculating the transferrin saturation (serum iron divided by the total iron-binding capacity) would be an appropriate initial evaluation for suspected hemochromatosis, but this typically manifests in a more subacute manner than alcohol-associated hepatitis. Ferritin is an acute-phase reactant and may be elevated in cases of alcohol-associated hepatitis but is not diagnostic of the condition.

E) INCORRECT:

A liver biopsy is an invasive test with potential complications and is reserved for indeterminate cases. It is therefore not indicated in this patient, who has a classic presentation for alcohol-associated hepatitis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with 10 days of jaundice, abdominal pain, and low-grade fever. He reports consuming 8–10 drinks daily for 15 years. Approximately 4 weeks ago, he decided to gradually cut down his alcohol consumption. His last drink was 2 days ago. Vital signs are BP, 115/75; P, 98; R, 18; T, 37.8°C (100°F). Physical examination shows scleral icterus, tender hepatomegaly, and trace ascites. The patient is alert and oriented and appears mildly anxious. He has a slight tremor in his hands bilaterally, but no asterexis. Laboratory results show AST 145 IU/L, ALT 78 IU/L, total bilirubin 5.8 mg/dL, INR 1.6, albumin 2.3 g/dL, creatinine 1.0 mg/dL, sodium 135 mEq/L, and WBC 12,800/mm³. MELD score is 19. Abdominal ultrasound shows hepatomegaly and trace ascites. Chest x–ray and urinalysis are unremarkable. Blood cultures are obtained. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the medical floor for monitoring and nutritional support
Admit to the medical floor for monitoring, nutritional support, and glucocorticoid therapy
Discharge with oral prednisolone and close outpatient hepatology follow-up
Admit to the medical floor for monitoring, nutritional support, and pentoxifylline therapy
Admit to the ICU and consult hepatology for consideration of early liver transplant

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – With a MELD score of 19, this patient has moderate acute alcohol-associated hepatitis that does not meet the threshold for severe disease (MELD > 20). The appropriate management includes admission for monitoring, alcohol withdrawal assessment, nutritional support with adequate caloric intake, and micronutrient supplementation. Glucocorticoid therapy is not indicated unless the MELD score exceeds 20.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid therapy is considered for severe alcohol-associated hepatitis with a MELD score > 20. This patient's MELD score is 19, which falls below the threshold for this treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Outpatient management is not appropriate for this patient. Patients with acute alcohol-associated hepatitis require inpatient monitoring for complications including alcohol withdrawal syndrome, infection, and progression of liver dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Pentoxifylline is no longer recommended for the treatment of alcohol-associated hepatitis, as it has not shown benefit in improving outcomes compared to standard supportive care.

E) INCORRECT:

ICU admission is reserved for patients with extrahepatic organ failure, stage III-IV hepatic encephalopathy, respiratory failure, or hemodynamic instability. Early liver transplant is usually considered in patients with severe alcohol-associated hepatitis (MELD score of >20) who do not respond to medical management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 10-day history of progressive fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and yellowing of her eyes. She reports drinking 6–8 glasses of wine daily for the past 12 years but stopped 3 days ago due to nausea. She reports being unable to tolerate more than a few bites of food due persistent nausea. Vital signs are temperature 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse 98/min, respirations 19/min, and blood pressure 108/72 mmHg. She appears fatigued, but is alert and oriented and has no asterixis. Physical examination shows scleral icterus, tender hepatomegaly, mild ascites, temporal wasting, and muscle wasting of the extremities. Laboratory studies show AST 165 IU/L, ALT 78 IU/L, total bilirubin 6.8 mg/dL, INR 1.9, albumin 2.4 g/dL, creatinine 1.2 mg/dL, and sodium 134 mEq/L. MELD score is 23. RUQ ultrasound shows hepatic steatosis without signs of biliary obstruction or portal vein thrombosis. Infectious workup is negative. Enteral nutrition is started through a nasogastric tube. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit for consideration of early liver transplant

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient meets consensus criteria for alcohol-associated hepatitis with recent jaundice onset, chronic heavy alcohol use, and characteristic liver chemistries in alcoholic hepatitis. She has severe disease based on a MELD score >20. Prednisolone is the treatment of choice for severe alcohol-associated hepatitis once infectious causes are excluded.

B) INCORRECT:

Pentoxifylline is no longer recommended for alcohol-associated hepatitis treatment, given the lack of demonstrated clinical benefit in improving outcomes.

C) INCORRECT:

Observation alone is inappropriate for severe alcohol-associated hepatitis with MELD score >20. This degree of liver dysfunction carries significant mortality risk and requires active pharmacological intervention beyond supportive care and nutritional management.

D) INCORRECT:

Lactulose is used for hepatic encephalopathy management. This patient demonstrates normal mental status with no asterixis, indicating absence of encephalopathy. Lactulose administration is not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Early liver transplantation is considered for patients who have failed to respond to initial medical management. This approach is not appropriate as first-line therapy before attempting other evidence-based treatments for severe alcohol-associated hepatitis.
